title: Improve MLLM Benchmark Efficiency through Interview
summary:
The rapid development of Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLM) has led to a
wide range of MLLM applications, and a number of benchmark datasets have sprung
up in order to assess MLLM abilities. However, full-coverage Q&A testing on
large-scale data is resource-intensive and time-consuming. To address this
issue, we propose the MLLM Interview (MITV) strategy, which aims to quickly
obtain MLLM performance metrics by quizzing fewer question. First, First, we
constructed the interview dataset, which was built on an existing MLLM
assessment dataset, by adding difficulty labels based on the performance of
some typical MLLMs in this dataset. Second, we propose an MLLM Interview
strategy, which obtains an initial performance situation of the large model by
quizzing a small number of topics and then continuously tries to test the
model's limits. Through extensive experiments, the result shows that the MITV
strategy proposed in this paper performs well on MLLM benchmark datasets, and
it is able to obtain the model evaluation capability faster through a small
number of questions and answers.

Figure 1: Motivation for our work. Redundancy in MLLM benchmark instances has been demonstrated [ 38], reducing the
efficiency of full benchmark evaluations. However, randomly sampling a small set of questions for evaluation is also inadequate.
Inspired by human interview processes, we propose an interview strategy that dynamically adjusts questions based on MLLM
performance, achieving more effective rankings than random sampling with the same number of questions.
Abstract
The rapid development of Multimodal Large Language Models
(MLLM) has led to a wide range of MLLM applications, and a num-
ber of benchmark datasets have sprung up in order to assess MLLM
abilities. However, full-coverage Q&A testing on large-scale data
is resource-intensive and time-consuming. To address this issue,
we propose the MLLM Interview (MITV) strategy, which aims to
quickly obtain MLLM performance metrics by quizzing fewer ques-
tion. First, First, we constructed the interview dataset, which was
built on an existing MLLM assessment dataset, by adding difficultylabels based on the performance of some typical MLLMs in this
dataset. Second, we propose an MLLM Interview strategy, which ob-
tains an initial performance situation of the large model by quizzing
a small number of topics and then continuously tries to test the
model’s limits. Through extensive experiments, the result shows
that the MITV strategy proposed in this paper performs well on
MLLM benchmark datasets, and it is able to obtain the model eval-
uation capability faster through a small number of questions and
answers.
--- Page 2 ---
Keywords
MLLM, Interview Strategy, Benchmark, Redundancy
1 Introduction
The rapid advancement of Multimodal Large Language Models
(MLLMs) has transformed numerous domains, enabling sophis-
ticated reasoning across text, images, and other data modalities.
Evaluating the performance of MLLMs is critical to understand-
ing their capabilities and limitations. Traditionally, MLLM evalua-
tion relies on comprehensive benchmarks comprising large sets of
standardized tasks. However, as MLLMs evolve in complexity and
benchmarks grow in scope, the computational and temporal costs of
full benchmark evaluations have become increasingly prohibitive,
prompting the need for more efficient evaluation methodologies.
Current MLLM benchmarks provide standardized metrics but of-
ten require evaluating models on thousands of questions to ensure
robustness. This exhaustive approach, while thorough, is redundant
and resource-intensive, particularly when benchmarking advanced
MLLMs with overlapping capabilities. The redundancy in bench-
marks stems from the inclusion of numerous questions that may
not significantly differentiate model performance, highlighting the
need for streamlined evaluation processes, as shown in the bench-
mark redundancy principle.
As depicted in Fig.2, an SRCC of 0.95 is achieved at a 40% sam-
pling rate across MLLM benchmarks, indicating that evaluating
MLLMs with just 40% of the benchmark instances yields perfor-
mance rankings nearly identical to those using the full benchmark
instances. However, beyond this point, further increases in the sam-
pling rate result in minimal SRCC improvement, highlighting the
presence of information redundancy in the benchmark.
To address the inefficiency of traditional benchmarks, we draw
inspiration from the human interview process. Experienced inter-
viewers can accurately assess a candidate’s abilities with only a few
carefully selected questions, adapting their inquiries based on re-
sponses to probe specific strengths and weaknesses. This dynamic
and adaptive approach contrasts with the static nature of bench-
marks, which apply a fixed set of questions regardless of a model’s
performance. Motivated by this, we propose an interview-based
evaluation framework for MLLMs, designed to replicate the effi-
ciency and adaptability of human interviews while maintaining the
rigor of benchmark assessments.
Our approach employs a powerful MLLM as an interviewer to
evaluate another MLLM (the interviewee). We begin by labeling
benchmark question instances with their difficulty and category,
creating a structured question pool. The interviewer MLLM lever-
ages this metadata to dynamically select questions, evaluate re-
sponses, and adjust subsequent questions based on the intervie-
wee’s performance. By iteratively refining the question selection,
the interviewer efficiently probes the interviewee’s capabilities
across diverse tasks and difficulty levels. The process culminates in
a final score that reflects the interviewee’s overall performance. The
experimental results show that the MITV strategy’s performance
is better than the Random strategy’s performance for the same
number of topics
Our work makes the following contributions:

Redundancy Principle [ 38]). Each data point reflects the

R2 score between rankings from sampled subsets and full
benchmark rankings.
•Construction of Interview Dataset : We construct a com-
prehensive interview dataset by integrating existing MLLM
benchmarks and annotating questions with difficulty and
category labels. This structured dataset enables targeted and
efficient evaluation across diverse dimensions and difficulty
levels.
•Interview-Based Evaluation Framework : We introduce
a dynamic, adaptive evaluation methodology for MLLMs,
inspired by human interviews, which significantly reduces
the number of questions needed compared to traditional
benchmarks. We develop a systematic approach to labeling
benchmark questions by difficulty and category, paired with
an intelligent question selection mechanism that optimizes
evaluation efficiency.
•Empirical Validation of Efficiency and Accuracy : We
demonstrate through experiments that our interview-based
approach achieves comparable ranking accuracy to full bench-
marks with a fraction of the questions, offering a scalable
solution for MLLM evaluation.
This work paves the way for more efficient and practical eval-
uation strategies, enabling rapid assessment of MLLMs in both
research and deployment contexts.
2 Related Works
This section reviews the evolution of Multi-modal Large Language
Models (MLLMs) and current benchmark-based evaluation paradigms.
2.1 Multi-modal Large Language Models
Multi-modal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have rapidly ad-
vanced, integrating diverse modalities such as vision and text to
perform complex tasks including visual question answering (VQA),
image captioning, and multimodal reasoning. Early models like
CLIP-ViT [ 24] established foundational visual-textual alignment.
Subsequent architectures, including GPT-4o [ 2], Gemini-1.5Pro [ 27],
--- Page 3 ---
and Qwen2-VL [ 30], demonstrate significantly enhanced capabil-
ities in complex reasoning and understanding, driven by scaled
architectures and extensive datasets [ 15,16]. Notable efforts like
InternVL [ 9] and LLaVAOneVision [ 18] further expand these capa-
bilities for generic tasks and domain transfer. This rapid progress
necessitates robust evaluation frameworks to assess their multifac-
eted abilities, from perception to high-level reasoning.
2.2 MLLMs Benchmark Evaluation
The evaluation of MLLMs predominantly relies on benchmarks
designed to assess specific capabilities like visual perception, rea-
soning, and domain-specific knowledge. Traditional benchmarks
such as GQA [ 15], VQA-V2 [ 4], and TextVQA [ 25] often employ
constrained, single-response formats, which may not fully capture
the sophisticated generative and interactive reasoning of advanced
MLLMs. Consequently, newer benchmarks like MMBench [ 20],
MMVet [ 35], and MMMU [ 36] have been introduced to evaluate
integrated multimodal capabilities. Specialized benchmarks such
as MathVista [ 21] for mathematical reasoning, OmniMedVQA [ 14]
for medical applications, and VRSBench [19].
However, the proliferation of these benchmarks has introduced
issues, notably redundancy. Zhang et al . [38] highlighted significant
overlaps by analyzing MLLM performance correlations, indicating
that many benchmarks may assess similar underlying abilities. Cri-
tiques by Chen et al . [8] and others further point to design limita-
tions, such as the inclusion of tasks with low discriminative power
or relevance, which can obscure true model capabilities [ 38]. While
the community strives for comprehensive and diverse evaluations
[12,34], these findings underscore the need for more principled
benchmark design to mitigate redundancy and enhance evaluative
efficiency. The current paradigm, largely dependent on static, prede-
fined test suites, may not adequately reveal the dynamic, adaptive,
and deeper reasoning faculties of state-of-the-art MLLMs. This sug-
gests an exigent need for novel evaluation methodologies capable
of more effectively probing these emergent, complex abilities.
3 Dataset Construct
3.1 Prepare Dataset
Traditional interview questions often lack systematicity and diffi-
culty gradient, which makes it difficult to comprehensively examine
the interviewer’s ability performance in different fields and at dif-
ferent difficulty levels. In this paper, we construct a dataset with a
difficulty gradient that can comprehensively test the comprehen-
sive ability of interviewers. This dataset integrates several existing
datasets, A-Bench[ 37], Q-Bench[ 31], MMT-Bench[ 33] and SEED-
Bench[ 17], covering multiple assessment dimensions such as logical
reasoning, multimodal comprehension, multitasking, and safety
ethics, which makes the data more three-dimensional.
3.2 Difficulty Calculation
In order to obtain the difficulty of each question quickly and fairly,
we judged the difficulty of the questions based on the performance
of several typical MLLMs on the target dataset. Specifically, Duan 𝑒𝑡
𝑎𝑙.[11] proposed VLMEvalKit, which is an open-source evaluation
toolkit of large vision-language models. VLMEvalKit provides a
powerful tool that helps us test the performance of different MLLMs.

For each benchmark mentioned in Sec.3.1, we uniformly chose
ten models, including GPT-4o[ 23], Deepseek-VL[ 32], Qwen-2.5-
VL[6],GeminiPro1-5[ 28], Grok-2[ 10], Kimi-VL[ 29], InternVL3[ 7],Cl-
aude3-7V[ 3], HunYuan[ 26] and Phi-3[ 1]. Then we judge the ques-
tion difficulty based on the performance of the chosen MLLM ac-
cording to Tab.1, it is worth noting that topics where none of the
ten models got it right we excluded.
After processing, we show the distribution of the difficulty of
the questions for different Benchmarks in the Fig.4. From the figure,
we can see that A) SEEDBench has a lower overall difficulty of
questions. B) MMT-Bench has a more even distribution of question
difficulty. C) Except for the MMT-Bench, the other three bench-
marks have a low distribution of high difficulty questions.
4 Proposed Method
In this section, we introduce the proposed MITV Strategy, which is
framed as shown in Fig. It consists of three main modules, which are
topic selection, interview, and result judgement. Firstly, the question
selection module selects the difficulty and category of the next
question based on the interviewee’s response. Then the interview
--- Page 4 ---
Figure 4: Difficulty distribution of questions in different
benchmarks.
module gives the selected question to the interviewee to answer.
Finally, the result analysis module judges the interviewee’s answers
and summarises the interviewee’s performance for the question
selection module’s judgement. The performance of the interviewees
is finally obtained through multiple rounds of interview questions
and answers.
4.1 Difficulty Determined
The difficulty determined module integrates information theory
and adaptive testing theory. Its core objective is to dynamically
adjust question difficulty to efficiently maximize information gain
about the model’s capabilities. Prior to evaluation, the model’s
ability interval is defined, assumed to be [0,10]. An initial estimate
is made using a bisection-like strategy, starting from the midpoint
of this interval.
The self-information formula from information theory serves as
the cornerstone for question selection. The information obtained
from a single observation is calculated as:
𝐼=𝑝0·log21
𝑝
·𝐶(𝑝)+𝑞0·log21
𝑞
·𝐶(𝑞)
where𝑝and𝑞denote the prior probabilities of the model answering
correctly and incorrectly, respectively, which can be manually con-
figured;𝑝0and𝑞0represent the observed probabilities of correct
and incorrect responses; 𝐶(𝑝)and𝐶(𝑞)are confidence functions.
This formula indicates that higher prior correctness probability 𝑝
yields less information, while lower 𝑝results in more information
gain, with confidence weighting applied.
During question selection, expected information gains for ques-
tions of varying difficulty levels are computed based on the current
ability estimate. Question difficulty ranges from 1 to 10, with em-
pirical accuracy expectations: 70% for Level 3, 50% for Level 5, and
30% for Level 7, and so on. Questions maximizing expected in-
formation are prioritized. If the model consistently answers easy
questions correctly, the difficulty is increased according to adaptive
testing theory; conversely, failures trigger a decrease in difficulty,
iteratively converging towards the interviewee’s ability level.Table 2: MLLM Interviewees Illustration. We utilize 9 closed-
source MLLM interviewees accessed via API calls and 10 open-
source MLLM interviewees deployed locally.

The feedback from the interviewer allows us to calculate the
amount of information in the interviewer’s answer to the previous
question, and if the amount of information is high, the difficulty of
the question is adjusted according to whether or not it answered
the question correctly. This process can be expressed as:

where𝐿𝑡denotes the difficulty level of the t-th question, 𝐼𝑡denotes
the amount of information in the response to the t-th question,
andℎ𝑖𝑡𝑡denotes the response to the t-th question, which is correct
if it is 1, and incorrect if it is the other way round. Although the
introduction of response informativeness can lead interviewers to
answer questions of comparable difficulty at their own level to a
greater extent, an uneven distribution of data difficulty can keep
interviewees under the same low or high difficulty level for a long

𝜃2. Ceteris paribus, 𝑅𝑙has a higher priority than 𝐼𝑡.
4.2 MLLM Interview Module
In order to make the interview questions more effective and typ-
ical, the module selects 10 different types of questions based on
the target level. We chose GPT-4o as the interviewer due to its
balanced performance. the interviewer MLLM selects a represen-
tative question from the selected questions, taking into account
the responses of the candidates, and then passes the question to
the candidate MLLM to answer. Through this systematic process
of question screening and interaction, it not only ensures that the
interview questions can accurately match the assessment needs,
but also flexibly adjusts the direction of the investigation based on
the interviewee MLLM feedback in the early stages, which helps
to assess the interview MLLM competency level in a more com-
prehensive and in-depth manner, and improves the accuracy and
relevance of the interview assessment.

4.3 Judgment Module
The judging module is mainly responsible for data processing in
the interview process, one is to check the answers of the interview-
ers.Due to the random nature of the MLLM answer content, we
use a Large language model (LLM) to perform a comprehensive
calibration of the interviewee’s competence in order to avoid the
difficulties posed by varying lengths of answers and redundancy of
answer information.
The judgment module is mainly responsible for the data pro-
cessing in the interview process, which is to verify the answers
of the interviewee. Due to the randomness of MLLM answers, we
use LLM to comprehensively verify the interviewee’s ability to
avoid the difficulties caused by the different lengths of answers and
the redundancy of answer information. Second, we calculate the
performance of the interviewee. This includes the correct rate at
different difficulty levels, the amount of information in the question
and answer session, and calculating the distribution of the intervie-
wee’s ability level after the interview. The judging module is able
to statistically analyse the interviewee’s performance information
in order to systematically make the next decision.5 Experiment
5.1 Experiment Detail
In order to validate the generalisation of MITV, we have selected 19
typical MLLMs, as detailed in Tab. 2. Among them, 9 large models
were validated using official API calls, and for the other MLLM
models, we used locally deployed models for the validation. To
verify the validity of MITV, we designed a control group whose
Benchmark questions were quizzed through a random sampling
strategy. It is worth noting that for the random sampling strategy
group experimental data we used VLMEvalKit [ 11] for uniform
testing. It is worth noting that for both sets of experiments, we
set up an absolute number of questions comparison and a relative
proportional number of questions comparison.
On each Benchmark, the full coverage test performance of the
model are used as the ground truth and three commonly used
metrics for algorithm assessment are applied: Spearman rank order
correlation coefficient (SRCC), Pearson linear correlation coefficient
(PLCC), and Kendall rank order correlation coefficient (KRCC).

5.2 Performance Discussion
The experimental results in Table 3 demonstrate the effectiveness
of the proposed MITV strategy compared to the random sampling
baseline across four MLLM benchmarks: A-Bench, Q-Bench, MMT-
Bench, and SEED-Bench. With closer inspections, we can obtain
several insights as follows:
5.2.1 Superior Performance of MITV. Across all benchmarks, MITV
achieves higher SRCC, PLCC, and KRCC scores than the random
sampling strategy on most question number settings, both in ab-
solute question counts (10 to 100 questions) and relative question
percentages (1% to 5%). The overview SRCC performance is shown
in Fig. 5. For instance, on A-Bench with 50 questions, MITV yields
an SRCC of 0.8250, compared to 0.6521 for random sampling—a
26.5% improvement. These results highlight MITV’s ability to pro-
duce rankings more aligned with full benchmark evaluations, even
with a limited number of questions.
5.2.2 Efficiency with Small Question Sets. MITV exhibits a signifi-
cant advantage when the number of questions is small. For example,
with just 10 questions on MMT-Bench, MITV achieves an SRCC of
0.7408, compared to 0.4830 for random sampling—a 53.4% improve-
ment. This high starting point underscores the efficiency of MITV’s
adaptive question selection, which leverages difficulty metadata
and performance feedback to target the most informative questions
early in the evaluation process. In contrast, random sampling strug-
gles to capture meaningful performance differences with limitedquestions, as it lacks the dynamic adjustment mechanism inherent
in MITV.
5.2.3 Generalization Across Benchmarks. The performance gains
of MITV are consistent across diverse benchmarks, demonstrating
its generalizability. On SEED-Bench, which has a larger benchmark,
MITV achieves an SRCC of 0.8088 with 50 questions, compared to
0.6102 for random sampling.On smaller benchmarks like Q-Bench
and MMT-Bench, MITV maintains its superiority, with SRCC values
exceeding 0.83 at 50 questions, approaching the accuracy of full
benchmark evaluations
6 Conclusion
Since the conventional Benchmark test is a full-coverage ques-
tion and answer test, there is information redundancy, in order
to optimise the evaluation method, this paper firstly constructs
several datasets with difficulty labels through the performance of
ten models on the existing Benchmark. Then the MITV strategy
is proposed, which can obtain the fastest model evaluation per-
formance through a small number of questions and answers by
converting the conventional full-coverage model performance test
into an interview ability evaluation. Through a large number of
experiments, it is proved that the proposed method is effective, has
good generalisation, and can provide suggestions and guidance for
MLLM assessment work.
